text:
Q: How do I determine the correct order of Lambda layers in AWS? A:

The merge order is the order in which the layers were added to the function, the last layer added/merged wins, and files are overwritten under /opt. This article on potential hijacks explains in more detail.

Q: Adding folders to GNUPLOT_LIB with set loadpath works fine, once. Has to be repeated for every new session A:

Please note that set loadpath in gnuplot only works for one session. You want to make it persistent.

When I run gnuplot interactively on Windows, I can add a custom folder to the load path like this:

set loadpath 'C:\Gnuplot\commands'
show loadpath

This works fine for the current session — I can load scripts from that folder without issues.
However, when I start a new gnuplot session, show loadpath no longer includes C:\Gnuplot\commands, and my scripts fail to load unless I repeat the set loadpath command.

Environmental Variable Option

Add a user or system environment variable:

GNUPLOT_LIB = C:\Gnuplot\commands;D:\other\path

Note: Use semicolons for multiple paths on Windows. Restart gnuplot and check with:

show loadpath

You should see your custom paths listed under the system section.

Startup File Option

Create or edit GNUPLOT.INI in your user directory (usually %USERPROFILE%). Add:

set loadpath 'C:\Gnuplot\commands'

Every time gnuplot starts, it will read this file and apply the setting.

Hope it helps

Q: Best method to loop a list while removing items A:

You probably want to sort the list (e.g. by interval start) first, so you only have to check adjacent entries instead of comparing every element with every element. Then, going backwards, from the end to the start of the list, would imply that only indices of already processed elements change.
